'''George Hege Hamilton IV''' (July 19, 1937 – September 17, 2014) was an American country musician. He began performing in the late 1950s as a [[teen idol]], switching to [[country music]] in the early 1960s.

==Biography==
Hamilton was born in [[Winston-Salem, North Carolina]], United States, on July 19, 1937,<ref name="LarkinGE">{{cite book|title=[[Encyclopedia of Popular Music|The Guinness Encyclopedia of Popular Music]]|editor=[[Colin Larkin (writer)|Colin Larkin]]|publisher=[[Guinness Publishing]] |date=1992 |edition=First |isbn=0-85112-939-0 |page=1065/6}}</ref> the son of [[Moravian Church|Moravian]] parents George Hege Hamilton III and Mary Lilian (née Pendry). He was introduced to country music by his paternal grandfather, a railroad worker. His great-grandfather, the first George Hege Hamilton, was a farmer, of a family that came from Scotland to America in 1685.<ref name="theguardian.com">{{Cite news|url=http://www.theguardian.com/music/2014/sep/18/george-hamilton-iv|title=George Hamilton IV obituary|date=September 18, 2014|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|access-date=March 21, 2022}}</ref><ref>http://www.capitol.tn.gov/Bills/106/Bill/SJR0811.pdf {{Bare URL PDF|date=March 2022}}</ref>

George Hamilton IV attended [[Richard J. Reynolds High School]], and is among several notable singers and songwriters to have attended that school, including [[Peter Holsapple]] and [[Greg Humphreys]]. While a 19-year-old student at the [[University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill]], Hamilton recorded "[[A Rose and a Baby Ruth]]" for a [[Chapel Hill, North Carolina|Chapel Hill]] record label, [[Colonial Records]].<ref name="LarkinGE"/> The song, written by [[John D. Loudermilk]], climbed to number six on the United States [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]] [[record chart|chart]].<ref name="LarkinGE"/> By 1960, "A Rose and a Baby Ruth" had attained [[music recording sales certification|gold record]] status for [[ABC Records|ABC-Paramount]] (which had acquired the song from [[Colonial Records|Colonial]]).<ref name="The Book of Golden Discs">{{cite book
| first= Joseph
| last= Murrells
| year= 1978
| title= The Book of Golden Discs
| edition= 2nd
| publisher= Barrie and Jenkins Ltd
| location= London
| page= [https://archive.org/details/bookofgoldendisc00murr/page/82 82]
| isbn= 0-214-20512-6
| url-access= registration
| url= https://archive.org/details/bookofgoldendisc00murr/page/82
}}</ref> The self-penned [[A-side and B-side|B-side]] of the record, "If You Don't Know, I Ain't Gonna Tell You", revealed Hamilton's ambitions to be a [[rockabilly]]-country singer.<ref name="LarkinGE"/>

After a string of pop hits, Hamilton joined the Rockabilly Tour playing with [[Eddie Cochran]], [[Buddy Holly]], [[the Everly Brothers]], [[Little Richard]], and several others throughout the country. Hamilton was then invited to [[Washington, DC]], to become a member of the cast of ''[[The Jimmy Dean Show]]'', where he performed regularly with [[Patsy Cline]] and [[Jimmy Dean]]. He also appeared on [[Dick Clark]]’s ''[[American Bandstand]]'', ''[[Arthur Godfrey's Talent Scouts]]'', and ''The Perry Como Show''. Hamilton went on to host his own national television musical/variety shows on ABC and CBS in the late 1950s. In late 1959, Hamilton moved his family to [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]] to further his work as a country musician.<ref name="LarkinGE"/><ref>"A Rose and a Baby Ruth" was issued in UK as "A Rose and a Candy Bar", as the [[Baby Ruth]] bar was unknown there.[https://web.archive.org/web/20070616060925/http://www.georgeiv.net/biog.html George Hamilton IV and Friends Biography Page]</ref> On February 8, 1960, Hamilton officially became a member of the ''[[Grand Ole Opry]]''.<ref>{{cite web
| title = George Hamilton IV
| url = http://www.opry.com/artists/h/HamiltonIV_George.html
| publisher = Grand Ole Opry
| access-date = June 29, 2012
| archive-date = March 13, 2017
| archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20170313012819/http://www.opry.com/artists/h/HamiltonIV_George.html
| url-status = dead
}}</ref><ref>{{cite web
 |title=Opry Member List PDF 
 |url=http://www.opry.com/img/Opry%20Members%20List.pdf 
 |date=April 23, 2012 
 |access-date=June 29, 2012 
 |url-status=dead 
 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120607030858/http://www.opry.com/img/Opry%20Members%20List.pdf 
 |archive-date=June 7, 2012 
}}</ref> Later that same year, he began recording for [[RCA Records]], having been signed by [[Chet Atkins]].<ref name="LarkinGE"/>

Hamilton's breakthrough hit was the 1961 song "Before this Day Ends". His biggest hit came two years later with "[[Abilene (song)|Abilene]]", another song penned by Loudermilk, along with [[Bob Gibson (musician)|Bob Gibson]] and Lester Brown.<ref name="LarkinGE"/> The song spent four weeks at number one on ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'''s country singles chart and reached the Top 20 of the Hot 100. The success of "Abilene" was followed with the song "Fort Worth, Dallas or Houston" (a [[Top 40|top-five]] hit in late 1964).<ref name="LarkinGE"/>

In 1962, Hamilton started the first Music City USA and Homes of the Stars Bus Tour in Nashville.  By the mid-1960s, Hamilton's music began showing a decidedly [[folk music|folk]] influence. This was especially evident with 1966's "Steel Rail Blues" and "[[Early Morning Rain]]" (both by [[Gordon Lightfoot]]), and 1967's "Urge for Going" penned by [[Joni Mitchell]].<ref name="LarkinGE"/> Another 1967 hit was "Break My Mind" (by John D. Loudermilk).<ref name="LarkinGE"/> One more Hamilton song of this genre was a moderate hit in 1969—the [[Ray Griff]]-penned "[[Canadian Pacific (song)|Canadian Pacific]]".<ref name="LarkinGE"/> His last top-five single came in 1970, with "She's a Little Bit Country".

After his American chart success declined in the early 1970s, Hamilton began touring the world, across the Soviet Union, Poland, Australia, the Middle East, and East Asia. Those widely acclaimed international performances earned Hamilton the nickname the International Ambassador of Country Music.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lib.unc.edu/mss/inv/h/Hamilton,George%5FIV.html|title=Inventory of the George Hamilton IV Papers at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill|publisher=Lib.unc.edu|access-date=September 18, 2014}}</ref> In the 1970s, Hamilton was the first American country singer to have his own British TV series on BBC. He also hosted a successful TV series in Canada for six years in the late 1970s. In the 1990s, he played himself in the [[West End theatre|West End]] musical ''Patsy'', based on the life of Patsy Cline.

In the 1980s, Hamilton appeared with [[Billy Graham]] on Ministry Tours throughout the United States and Canada, and including the UK tour "Mission England".<ref name="LarkinGE"/>

In 2004, he recorded an acoustic [[Southern gospel|gospel]] album with producer [[Dave Moody (musician)|Dave Moody]] titled ''On a Blue Ridge Sunday'', which earned Hamilton a [[Dove Award]] nomination in the "Best [[Bluegrass (music)|Bluegrass]] Album of the Year" category by the members of the Gospel Music Association. A single from the album, "Little Mountain Church House", won nominee recognition in the "Best Bluegrass Recorded Song" category the following year.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gospelmusic.org/newsmedia/pressRoom.aspx |title=GMA Press Room Online |work=Gospel Music Association |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100706172400/http://www.gospelmusic.org/newsmedia/pressRoom.aspx |archive-date=July 6, 2010 }}</ref>

Until the very late years of his life, Hamilton was a regular at the ''Grand Ole Opry'' in Nashville and in country shows throughout the U.S. and the UK. Hamilton celebrated his 50th year as a ''Grand Ole Opry'' member in 2010.  He mainly concentrated on gospel tours both at home and abroad. In 2007, he collaborated with Live Issue,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.liveissue.ik.com/|title=Official Live Issue Website|publisher=Liveissue.ik.com|access-date=September 18, 2014|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090622101923/http://www.liveissue.ik.com/|archive-date=June 22, 2009}}</ref> a group from [[Northern Ireland]], to record a live album based on the life of [[Joseph Scriven]], who wrote the [[hymn]] "[[What a Friend We Have in Jesus]]". The two also toured together again in 2009.

In 2008, at the height of the soaring U.S. gas prices, Hamilton released "Gasoline", a parody of his classic hit "Abilene".  The acoustic single featured "The Oil Spots" (a.k.a. the Moody Brothers & George Hamilton V) and became a hit with audiences during Hamilton's Opry appearances. Hamilton was also a regular participant in the ''Country's Family Reunion'' video series.

In 2010, [[Lamon Records]] released the album ''Old Fashioned Hymns'', recorded transatlantic with producers Dave Moody in Nashville and Colin Elliott in Ireland. Hamilton was joined on the 28-track collection by a number of musical guests, including [[Ricky Skaggs]], [[Marty Stuart]], [[Gail Davies]], [[Pat Boone]], [[Del McCoury]], [[Bill Anderson (singer)|Bill Anderson]], [[Connie Smith]], [[Tommy Cash]], [[Cliff Barrows]], and [[George Beverly Shea]], among others.

== Personal life and death ==
Hamilton married his high school sweetheart Adelaide "Tink" Peyton and had two sons, George and Peyton, and one daughter, Mary. When Hamilton's elder son George Hege Hamilton V was seven years old, he found one of his father's guitars and began writing songs. He became a singer, using the name "Hege V" because his father and the [[George Hamilton (actor)|actor, George Hamilton]] were already both using the same name. The younger Hamilton said his father "never pushed me", but he eventually began playing in nightclubs. On his tours, which sometimes included his father, Hege V played rhythm guitar and sang harmony and occasionally the lead, including some of his father's songs.<ref>{{cite news |last=Hurst |first=Jack |date=June 8, 1987 |title=Hege V Dries His Tears, Hits the Road for 'House' |work=[[Chicago Tribune]] |url=https://www.chicagotribune.com/news/ct-xpm-1987-06-08-8702120091-story.html |access-date=29 January 2019}}</ref> George has four grandchildren including George Hege "Nash" Hamilton VI,<ref name="theguardian.com" /> Peyton McAlester Hamilton, Aubrey Elizabeth Arcure, and James Michael "Mick" Arcure.{{citation needed|date=January 2022}}

Hamilton had a heart attack on September 13, 2014, and died on September 17 at [[Saint Thomas - Midtown Hospital (Nashville)|Saint Thomas Midtown Hospital]] in Nashville.<ref>{{cite web |title=Opry star George Hamilton IV dead at age 77 |url=http://www.tennessean.com/story/entertainment/music/2014/09/17/george-hamilton-iv-year-opry-star-dies-age/15808327/ |access-date=September 17, 2014 |work=The Tennessean}}</ref> On September 24, the [[Ryman Auditorium]] hosted a memorial service, which included performances by Marty Stuart, Ricky Skaggs, the Whites, [[Jett Williams]], Gail Davies, Connie Smith, Dave Moody, Jimmy Capps, Barry and Holly Tashian, the Babcocks, Andrew Greer, and [[Cindy Morgan]]. Those who shared stories of Hamilton's life and career at the memorial service included English music historian and journalist Tony Byworth, music writer and author Frye Galliard, artists and songwriters John D. Loudermilk and Bill Anderson, Grand Ole Opry general manager Pete Fisher, and [[WSM (AM)|WSM]] announcer Eddie Stubbs. The service concluded with "Amazing Grace" performed on bagpipes by Nashville Pipes and Drums Pipe Sergeant David Goodman.<ref>{{cite web |date=September 24, 2014 |title=George Hamilton Iv Memorial Service |url=http://spoonercentral.com/HamiltonMemorial.html |access-date=17 August 2015 |publisher=Spoonercentral.com}}</ref> George Hamilton IV is buried in [[God's Acre Cemetery (Old Salem)|God's Acre Cemetery]] in [[Old Salem]], North Carolina.<ref>[https://www.cityofws.org/DocumentCenter/View/24724/George-Hamilton-IV-Bio?bidId=#:~:text=**George%20Hamilton%20IV%20was,in%20High%20School%20Talent%20Contests. Mr. George Hamilton IV Background information]  – City of Winston-Salem</ref>

The George Hamilton IV Collection is located in the [[Southern Folklife Collection]] of the Wilson Library of the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill.<ref>{{Cite web |title=George Hamilton IV Collection, 1956–2013 |url=http://finding-aids.lib.unc.edu/20410/ |access-date=6 November 2017 |website=finding-aids.lib.unc.edu}}</ref>

==Honors ==
Hamilton was inducted into the [[North Carolina Music Hall of Fame]] in 2010.<ref>{{cite web|title=2010 Inductees|url=http://northcarolinamusichalloffame.org/category/inductees/2010-inductees/|publisher=North Carolina Music Hall of Fame|access-date=September 10, 2012}}</ref>

The North Carolina Board of Transportation voted to name a bridge on [[Interstate 40 Business (Winston-Salem, North Carolina)|Business 40]] for Hamilton. The ceremony naming the bridge was held on July 19, 2016, which would have been Hamilton's 79th birthday.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.journalnow.com/news/local/business-bridge-named-after-george-hamilton-iv/article_063aadd7-20e8-5b9c-9558-968326977cbf.html|title=Business 40 bridge named after George Hamilton IV|last=Evans|first=Meghann|work=[[Winston-Salem Journal]]|date=October 9, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.journalnow.com/news/local/winston-salem-bridge-renamed-in-honor-of-music-star-george/article_6e5ae7c1-a6a4-5dc0-a595-5c312fad68c2.html|title=Winston-Salem bridge renamed in honor of music star George Hamilton IV|last=Hinton|first=John|work=Winston-Salem Journal|date=July 19, 2016}}</ref>
